My house Champagne! Pinot dominant (at 70%) so you get red berries and cherries, and with some of the citrus and stone fruit of the Chardonnay (30%). Lots of autolytic character but not at the expense of fruitiness. This is versatile Brut (4.8 g/L dosage) and great value.

Very vinous champagne. Nose of apples and pear, with some brioche. In the mouth there are lots of tiny bubble giving it a foamy texture. Very smooth and very complex throughout the mouth. A lot of things happening especially on the finish.

Another beautiful champagne from the weekend. This one spent 3 years on its lees. 70% Chardonnay and 30% Pinot noir. Toasted bread, honey, hazelnut, lemon...yummmm. Super vinous as well. Medium body and medium + acidity. Loved this.

Though this is listed as non-vintage, the large majority of this 70%/30% (PN/Chardonnay) Grand Cru Champagne is from the 2012 vintage. The nose is spectacular and comprised of red apple, lemon curd, white flowers, toasted bread/dough, and almond. The palate continues with some red fruits, marzipan, lemon curd, and bread notes. Fantastic Champagne at an amazing price. I‚Äôm going to try to forget a bottle for a few years.... not sure it will make it though.

J.M. Labeuyeres Grand Cru NV Champagne is a masterpiece made from 70% Pinot Noir and 30% Chardonnay. Classic high acidity and dryness, and with a delicious note structure of citrus, apple, pear, peach and a fine taste of hazelnut and brioche. All flows elegant and well balanced and remember to buy bottles ..... You surely want to taste again tomorrow.

Super minerally initially, like biting into a very bubbly piece of blackboard chalk. Would not have pegged this at 60% PN. Opened up a bit with air/temp and showed more yellow apples and stone fruit. Needs more time to shine, but great QPR!

70% PN 30% Chardonnay. 2013 harvest, 2014 bottling, 2018-2019 disgorgement. Eye: medium burnished gold. Nose: marzipan, almonds, sultanas, some dense heavy floral notes, limestone minerality, some apricot and poached pear, some muted pineapple notes. High fine carbonation and high acidity with just a little sugar to ameliorate the biting dryness. Tasty with this triple creme brie. Light butter, hint of saline. Favorite affordable champagne; would happily buy again at $50-55.

Second time with this champagne and it has to be one of my favourites, and demonstrates so well that Grower-Producer champagnes are where to look for huge QPR, as well as some unique wines. 

3 years on the lees here, 5 years of bottle age at this point, 70% PN to 30% Chardonnay. 

Baked apple pie is the best way to describe this champagne for both the palate and nose, accompanied by bruised apple, Granny Smith, good acidity, and some red fruit notes on the palate. 

A winner!

Owners have interests in multiple Domaines across France Vineyards, included Bordeaux and Bourgogne. 

This Champagne is made with a Burgundian approach: 
- specific climates are selected (all on Montagne de Reims, Grand Cru Verzenay and Verzy) 
- harvest is slightly later than other growers
- full malolactic is made
- a bit is aged in oak

The result, a champagne with a lower acidity, yet the no dosage give the tension through dryness. 
Apple, cream, yeast and bruised apple towards the end.
